trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

threat_severity.level_description: Severity NONE because the file has no Google antivirus detections and no bad network activity

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros appear to be benign and do not exhibit any signs of malicious intent. Here's a detailed analysis of their behavior:

1. ThisDocument.cls:
   - This module contains class declarations and attribute definitions for the document.
   - It sets various attributes related to the document's name, base class, global namespace, creatable status, predefined ID, exposure, template derivation, and customizability.
   - These attributes are used to define the properties and behavior of the document object in Microsoft Word.

2. NewMacros.bas:
   - This module contains a single macro named "autoopen()".
   - The "autoopen()" macro is executed automatically when the document is opened.
   - The macro simply displays a message box with the number "1" using the MsgBox function.

There are no indications of obfuscation, decoding of base64, suspicious function calls, attempts at persistence, manipulation of macro security settings, writing entries in the Windows registry, downloading, writing, or executing .exe files, self-replication mechanisms, disabling of alerts or screen updating, or any other behaviors commonly associated with malware or macro viruses.

The macros are straightforward and perform basic actions within the expected functionality of Microsoft Word.

The provided macros do not exhibit any signs of malicious intent. The first macro, "ThisDocument.cls", appears to be a standard document class in Visual Basic for Applications (VBA). It does not contain any code that would execute upon opening the document or at any other time. It simply sets several attributes related to the document itself, such as its name and whether it is derived from a template.

The second macro, "NewMacros.bas", contains a subroutine named "autoopen()". This subroutine is automatically executed when the document is opened. However, the only action this subroutine performs is displaying a message box with the number 1. There are no suspicious function calls, attempts at persistence, manipulations of macro security settings, entries written in the Windows registry, downloads or executions of .exe files, self-replication mechanisms, or disabling of alerts and screen updating. 

In conclusion, based on the provided macros, there is no evidence of obfuscation, base64 decoding to write or execute files, or any other indicators commonly associated with malware or macro viruses.
